78819323.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
[b]Green Hell[/b] is a single-player and co-op survival game set in a tropical rainforest. Players impersonate an anthropologist that, along with his fiancée Mia, led an expedition to a remote forest for studying an ancient indigenous tribe. After a promising beginning, things go downhill quickly as the couple gets separated and players are left fending for themselves in the middle of the wilderness. Starting from scratch, the protagonist will need to learn how to survive, fight, hunt and explore - with the final objective of finding Mia and escape from the forest.

🟩 [b]The Good Side[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Uncompromising realism[/b]
Green Hell is one of the most realistic, down-to-earth survival games around. The way crafting, building and generally all other activities are performed is heavily oriented towards real-life counterparts without shortcuts. For instance, crafting is always done by hand, picking up items one by one and combining them together in a slow-paced process. The same goes for building camping facilities, healing and inventory management. The game also promotes experimenting to find new recipes: if this may sound annoying worry not, it's well thought out and works brilliantly.

[*][b]A proper namesake[/b]
Full of predators, venomous animals and hostile natives, the forest can be really called "Green Hell". Every inch may hide deadly insects or animals, whose venoms or inflicted wounds take time and many resources to heal. Natives may decide to attack one's base in the middle of the night without warning, while infections, parasites, fatigue and madness also some of the most conspicuous enemies. The world however also houses many tools, secret locations and rich 'treasures' for those skilled enough to find a way through this unforgiving land.

[*][b]Journeying against all odds[/b]
The main story will see players embark into daring expeditions into the wilderness, in order to find tools, equipment and resources to progress in other parts of the forest. Without any hand-holding, it's up to the protagonist to find out what has to be done next. Along with this struggle, memories and visions will accompany Jake, revealing more about his past and the events that transpired. Travel light, or build camps and outposts to have some safe haven across the forest: any approach is entirely viable, but some may be harder. Multiple endings available.
[/list]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2278334696

🟥 [b]The Bad Side[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Bugs, and not the poisonous kind[/b]
Especially in co-op, Green Hell proves to be still rather buggy an unpolished. From minor annoyances such as glitchy colliders to major problems like players not getting their progress / inventory state saved correctly or enemies popping out of thin air instantly killing someone, there definitely are issues. None of them was game-breaking in my experience, but for sure can be very frustrating to lose items or progress because of such issues.
[/list]

[h3]Rating: Very Good[/h3]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1989090445]Click here for the complete Rating Chart[/url]
[i]It took me, along with other two people, 20 hours to complete Green Hell. This time may vary greatly based on number of players and also playstyle. Delivering very good quality despite some bugs, I can recommend getting this game for full price.[/i]

[quote]Liked this review, and want to see more of the same quality? Check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/39323490]Tamaster's Review Archive[/url] to see all my Reviews in a single, convenient location.[/quote]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2278335969

[h1]In-Depth Breakdown[/h1]
🎮 [b]Gameplay Analysis[/b]
Gameplay is divided into Exploration, Character Management, Crafting and Combat.

[b]Exploration[/b]
Is performed on foot, across the vast wilderness. At first many areas of the forest are closed, requiring specific gear such as climbing hooks or diving equipment to get through. A map is available for the initial area, but it's already damaged - while for more advanced zones maps need to be found in remote places. Exploring is essential to find food, water and supplies for crafting - which will be in constant demand as players progress. The map is reasonably large and has many secondary areas which may even lead to different endings if time is taken to read the lore found.

[b]Character Management[/b]
Is perhaps the most ubiquitous activity. Four resources (Carbs, Proteins, Fats and Water) determine the character's maximum health level, and degrade over time or faster in case of sickness or other conditions. Each food gives different nutrients, so an actually balanced diet is recommended to not have debuffs. Infections, parasites and other ailments all can occur and require specific medicine for each - they can also be waited out, but survival is not guaranteed.

The inventory system uses both space and weight as limits to what one can carry, which is not a whole lot of stuff. More weight equals to more stamina consumed to travel around, which in turn means sleeping more often to regain it. Being at all times stocked with tools, healing items and food is one of the top priorities in Green Hell, otherwise survival becomes arduous. Dying means losing a part of the inventory and major durability loss on everything else, which can be recovered at the place of death.

[b]Crafting[/b]
Is done in a realistic manner either in the crafting panel (for smaller items such as tools or bandages) or on the ground in case of larger base facilities, such as house frames, smokers, racks and so on. In both cases, each component needs to be delivered manually with limited inventory capacity, so getting anything done requires time other than effort in finding the things. In many cases also, byproducts and refined materials are needed to do so, such as molten metal that requires a furnace that in turn requires many other things. Realistic, as it should be.

[b]Combat[/b]
Is done against Natives and Predators. It's not very complex, and has a block function / dodging to avoid blows, while also charged attacks and varied usage modes for some weapons (spears can be thrown or used in melee as example). Headshots with bows and pointy things in general one-shot without mercy, while enemies are generally quite spongy to normal hits. Armor can be made to heavily reduce taken damage, while fighting without one will result in a quick death. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2278334661

[h2]Technical Corner[/h2]
[u]Specs: RTX 2080Ti, Ryzen 9 3900X, 32GB RAM, 970 PRO NVME SSD[/u]

[list]
[*][b]Critical Problems[/b]
- Sometimes, player positions and inventory are saved incorrectly in co-op, leading to items / progress loss.

[*][b]Performance[/b]
Average VRAM Usage: 4.5 to 5.5 GB
Average GPU Utilization: 70-90%
Settings Used: All High, Sliders Half, 1440p 60Hz
Overall Optimization Rating: Terrible

[*][b]Bugs & Other Issues[/b]
- Instant death enemies (like Caimans) can spawn on top of players out of thin air in certain areas.
- In co-op, chest container inventory may get glitched, showing different things from one player to another.
- In co-op, desync problems can happen, showing dead animals alive for another player and similar issues.
- Animations and physics are clunky, inclined to glitch relatively often.
[/list]

96482967.review:
Survival games have become extremely popular over the last few years, which has led to an influx of titles that attempt to offer something new and challenging. Unfortunately most fail, which has led to suspicion of "cashing in" when new titles arrive on the market.

Green Hell has attempted a slightly different and much more realistic take on the genre, where micro-management is key to your success. And it's not bad, really!

You see, most survival games balance their challenge with food, water and odd dangers, such as mutant babies or zombies. They scale your consumption to ridiculous levels (gallons of fluids and kilos of food every day) to supposedly balance their gameplay. By doing so, they reduce the realism of the players adventure and inject frustration in how much of a need there is to gather nourishment over all else. It seems to be the 'go to' formula for the generic survival game... Not so in Green Hell.

There's pretty much everything you could want here. A large, sprawling rain forest that's been lovingly crafted in stunning detail (imagine Crysis on steroids). There's danger everywhere, from small parasites and insects to dangerous animals. The locals are also not happy you are in their territory, so inevitably they want to disrupt your progress (in small ways) and will even attempt to engage you in combat. Not enough to make it an irritation, but enough to have you on your toes and to raise your pulse. Even simple sounds can have you imagining the worst and set you on edge.

Sustenance is very well integrated, with not just water or food, but a complex mixture of hydration, protein, fats and carbohydrates that all need attention if you don't want to suffer exhaustion, starvation, or even go mad and start hearing voices. Eating some foods can directly affect your sanity, such as eating human flesh or creepy crawlies. Cooking homely foods can soothe your woes and restore your sanity. All of this adds a complex and rewarding mini-game in itself. Although it can make the early days very demanding, it is a refreshing take on human needs in this genre of game.

Crafting is also a real treat here. It's complex and hard work. There's no cutting down trees for 500 wood and spamming walls and items everywhere. Gathering is its own challenge, with weight issues and item availability being a core element to expansion of your home base should you decide to make one.

The list of craftables starts small, meaning you ideally need to explore to discover how to make something. You can, however, experiment with smaller recipes and stumble into their various schematics (which unlock once crafted). So common sense is also your friend here! A nice little touch (similar to Minecraft) that makes the game feel more like a simulator than a game.

Illness, injuries, parasites and other disabilities are also micro managed, with a knowledge of local herbs and plants essential to a speedy recovery. You need to consider your own hygiene. Being dirty makes a difference when eating or applying medicine. The consequence of which can be gross.

TLDR:
I'm still discovering many things as I play and am amazed at the love that's been put into the development of this game. It's truly a fantastic experience for anyone that's looking for a serious survival adventure that pushes your abilities of thought and reason. It's not for the feint of heart or the impatient. I'm not even sure it can be classed as a game. Simulator is a far more accurate description, but there is a story included (EA Tutorial, with the main story being added in v1.0 Official Release), which adds purpose.

Extremely well executed and highly recommended!

140513213.review:
Green Hell is a great game because it delivers on what it promises. It's a survival crafting game. And it does that better than all competitors out there. Basebuilding is amazingly satisfying. Crafting is logical and cool. Survival is an actual challenge and offers soooo much more detail than every other survival game. You can get infections, lacerations, abrasions, fever, poison, vomiting, parasites, worms, rashes.. and you need to avoid and/or treat them all. Hygiene is important, you need to constantly check yourself for leeches, pay attention to scorpions, spiders and snakes.. You need to keep all your macronutrients like proteins, fats and carbohydrates up, make sure you get clean water and you need to explore the jungle and get to know it's plants, mushrooms and all the other things the jungle has to offer..

But don't expect it to be easy. Sometimes you can feel like there is nothing threatening you anymore, you get carless and a snake bites you. No problem.. you got anti-venom dressings to treat the wound. But then the poison gives you fever. Fever makes you thirsty. So you drink all of your water. But you feel okay and keep going. But then that snakebite gets infected. So you put maggots on the wound to eat off the infected flesh. But that raises your fever and all of the sudden you're thirsty again. Water is gone. So you drink some dirty river water. Even more fever. You decide to head home. But you are losing energy super fast now and pass out in the middle of the jungle. You wake up infested with worms. You remove them using Fishbones and treat the open wounds with ash-dressings. But you are so sick now that you keep passing out and you get infested with worms again and again. After half an hour you make it back to base and with the last percent of energy you make it into your hammock. Just to die because the infections killed you in your sleep.

Look i could go on. But if the above sounds like fun, you should buy this game.

48584836.review: The survival element and the graphics effects in Green Hell is an amazingly realistic experience playing in "Welcome to the Jungle" or medium difficulty setting. I have personally been lost in the same environment twice in the same Amazonian Jungle. I barely survived the ordeal and swore "NEVER AGAIN". That was in 1999 in French Guyana. In the game - especially the insanity element, the emerging panic and the constant quest for finding food while slowly starving  is very realistic and and reminds me of my own adventure: A friend and I ventured 2 days past the last outpost only carrying shotguns, rice and medicine believing we could live off the land... BIG MISTAKE... after 4 days we had been eating only a King Fisher bird, 1 small piranha palm tree marrow and lots of rice of course. We were stalked while canooing by an adult jaguar (ca. 110kg adult average) .. we saw its footprints and heard it scream like a cat on steroids and jump around few tens of meters away but never saw it. Although we had been catious to clean our water we got sick after 7 days in the jungle.. my friend got painful fungus infection in the ears, fingers and feet and me a killer fever that rose to an incredible 40,5. We barely made it back to the hospital in St. Laurent alive. (I got intravenous penicilline for 2 hours at the hospital.) The constant buggery of insects were driving us mad and we constantly had to check for ants and termites in our pants. We eventually found out that smoking our own clothes and tying pants and shirts to wrists and ankles, helped keep most of the bugs away. Or the termites that ate our carbet (bivouak) so that our hammocks crashed to the ground in the middle of the night. Before we left the Foreign Legion asked us to please inform them about our intended route "Why?" "So that we know where to look if or when you go missing." This game offers realism even down to the abandoned drug processing camp and the suspect natives. Oh yes - this game is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

119602173.review:
Green Hell is not a game.  It's an experience.  In this leech removing simulator, you play as Jake Higgins, an absolute imbecile of a man who can't walk over logs or tell which part of his body hurts without inspecting every limb and packs his bag like a die-hard Tetris fan.  He can't carry more than 50-pounds on his back without crawling on the ground and thought it was a good idea to wear t-shirt and shorts to one of the most dangerous environments in the world.  At least he had the foresight to not wear sandals or crocs.  Jake Higgins is simultaneously a strong man and yet one of the weakest men you'll ever meet.  You'll be able to tear apart logs with your bare hands and carry 2 logs on your shoulder at once but be unable to carry 7 banana leaves.  He has a 2-inch vertical jump and can run for about 200 feet on a good day.  

You'll start your game out with normal nutrient depletion not realizing Jake has every single tapeworm in Brazil in his body and then go turn it down after you realize you just spent the past 5 hours of game play foraging for food to keep your vitals up.  Perhaps to augment his unusual body composition, you will learn that he needs a full 8 hours of sleep every 4 hours and needs to eat his body weight in food in those 8 hours and runs the risk of dying by dehydration no less than 3 times in those 8 hours.  He has an aversion to eating human meat and spiders but is down to snack on human bones and rubbing those spiders into a wound.  

But enough about him, let's go onto the actual game.  Green Hell is a survival game where harvesting resources is incredibly easy but tedious and slow.  Harvesting resources is a matter of pressing E randomly while walking around or a few swings with an axe.  Like most survival games that use wood, you can't cut down like 90% of the trees but the trees you can cut down takes like 4 swings of the axe to drop.  Trees drop 2 logs and 2 long sticks but recipes will need 3 logs or long sticks.  You'll get at most 10 rocks in your play through so make sure you treasure them.  Food and water is a non-issue because eating random things off the ground as you travel around will not only suffice, they can and will cure any ailments you have.  

You can hear literally every threat to your well being before you see them and pull out your trusty level 1 bow to instantly kill the aggressor.  Once you have your trusty level 1 bow (something you can get 10 seconds into the game) and 2 arrows (just in case you miss your first shot), you are set to beat the game.  Once you get armor (something you can do 10 seconds into the game), it doesn't even matter if you missed your first shot as you have become immortal.

The base building portion of Green Hell demonstrates how strong mud walls and jungle tribal men are.  Tribal enemies will be able to decimate any mud wall with nothing more than a knife and 3 swings.  Sometimes the structures you build are so flimsy and porous, enemies and animals will just walk through them to attack you without damaging the wall at all.  

Directional audio is actually amazing once you get past hearing random leaves rustling, random wooden items banging around and Jake Higgins complaining about being hungry, sleepy or thirsty or simply angrily swearing every few seconds.

You start off with a watch that can do everything except wipe your rear end and assemble a plane to fly out.  You're trying to find your wife who has been a champ to put up with your 94 tapeworms and demanding sleep requirements.  In summary, the two good points of Green Hell are the directional audio and the actual story and plot.  Green Hell touts itself as difficult and realistic but the only realistic part of the game is going insane when playing it.

71716906.review:
[h1]Green Hell isn't just another survival game[/h1]

Most of the "survival" games have very basic and simplistic mechanics with food and water. Here developers took care about details, expanded what is a standard in survival genre and created interesting, fun mechanics. 

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- not so simple survival mechanics
- beautiful environment design and "feeling" of a jungle
- realistic and fun approach to food, player health, crafting and building (you can use real life knowledge in this game for your advantage)
- the way how you learn about the game mechanics
- really enjoyable coop experience
- decent tutorial
- story seems to be alright, a bit predictable imho
- not too bad character levelling - basic, but works

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- at first slighty clunky UX/Ui
- not so intuitive notebook where you keep all your known crafting recipes, it looks immersive, but isn't so functional
- after a while game challenge drops once you establish shelter and basic source of water and food, which isn't difficult to accomplish
- only one, not so large map
- animals or tribesmans aren't a big challenge - easy to trick and defeat

[h1]Would I recommend Green Hell?[/h1]
[b]Short answer Yes[/b]
Long story: Game can become much better product, as long as developer keeps adding new content. I'm aware that new gamemode has been announced, but after 26 hours of game I'd like to see more to keep me interested. Game updates that would include:
- new, larger map (dynamically generated map would be extra +)
- more challenge
- more aggressive and new enemies/predators
- more constructions
- more meals
- redesign of crafting menu
- body temperature mechanics perhaps?

Last, but not least price - you can grab it for 25-35PLN (10$), which is fair price for this amount of content this game has to offer.

139150804.review: ENJOY THE PAIN, DONT GOOGLE ANYTHING, BE A MAN

44701614.review:
I loved this game for the first 2 or 3 days playing it. However, after figuring out the game mechanics and getting a home base set up the game becomes extremely boring. Water is very easy to collect with coconuts and fish is very plentiful and easy to catch. The big gerbil looking thing are very easy to kill for meat. I have crafted everything available. Items like the bamboo smoker and grill make loading up on food easy. I have explored all over and after you go to the known "loot" spots there is anything left to see really. The available loot like chips, juice, peanuts, and a rusty machete is pretty much all there is...like literally.... that’s it. 

The game is fantastic but after mastering the survival part and exploring for about a day....it leaves you without much to do and in the constant cycle of cook, eat, rain, drink, sleep, remove leech. A great start for an early access but anxious for more.

The success of this game greatly depends on how much it gets developed. The small preview of the story is fantastic, and I know that will make things interesting. I just hope the game comes to full release soon instead of later or never like a lot of early release games.

89260458.review:
Building mechanics is like no other. It is very limited at the same time too realistic. Everything needs a certain foundation. Realistically-crazy I should point that out even in the process of making a mud-concrete, you literally need to grab some mud, mix it with some ash and water. The fruit of labor, all for the love of building.

Inventory & crafting mechanics is insanely hand-wrought. You have to memorize the materials needed in crafting certain items. And yea, not every detail is written in your notes - only the basic ones are stated there. You gotta explore not just the map but as well as crafting - funny thing is that, in order to live you have to explore/experience every living and non-living creature to know and gain knowledge from, which makes death inevitable.

Hunger & thirst is not just the mechanics here and it's not even half as scary as falling ill or acquiring certain diseases, having some rashes or worm inside your skin, being poisoned and insane. Insanity is really not just visually disturbing but as well as audibly tormenting.

Sanity mechanics is somewhat like "Don't Starve Together", whenever someone died from your server, you loses sanity and when your sanity reach to certain point, you can see/hear some sanity enemies nearby which you could either kill or ignore. [spoiler]Staying at a fireplace helps recover your sanity.[/spoiler]

Overall, I find the game very challenging. It adopts every concept & possibilities there is to provide a more realistic survival experience in Amazonian rainforest.

51446666.review: I have survived 142 days give or take a few. I lost count after the first month lost in this quagmire of lush terrible beauty! On my first day I had made my way to the site of a plane crash, and found a cave that some survivor must have lived in. There was a bed ready made, and some food stuffs, and crafting supplies. I made an axe, and constructed a simple shelter outside the cave,  which allowed me to save my progress. I then made a bamboo spear and with practice I was able to down some small animals. Two banana trees nearby provided much needed nutrients! I kept an eye on my watch, and checked my nutritional needs regularly. Water was an issue here, but after I harvested some coconut shells, I was able to boil water and make it drinkable! I built some other amenities and explored the area near and far. I set up a couple of other save sites in advantageous locations so as to facilitate easy travel, and to begin alternative camp sites. I had encountered Natives a couple of times and avoided them, but I was wounded badly in a later attack and had to convalesce. Fortunately I had crafted some ash bandages earlier! I was forced to move my main base after one awful horrifying attack by a raiding group of natives. I managed to slay four from the refuge of my cave,( they will not enter caves), with my bow and arrow. I wish I had crafted more arrows but alas I ran out of ammunition and had to make a run for it as they were going to starve me out! I ran, and ran, and I could hear them howling as they chased me. They moved faster than me and knew the area well. I tried to zig zag to avoid their arrows which whizzed past my head.Finally I hid in the brush below a small rise and they ran past! I circled back and then followed a cliff line south, to an abandoned native village. I set up a temporary camp here, as it had its advantages! Now, I am in an isolated part of the jungle, accessible by only a log crossing a high ravine. The natives had destroyed everything I had built in my first camp, and so now I am rebuilding, and gathering my courage to venture forth! Come join me on this adventure! It is horrifyingly awesome, and tense at times but it has a beauty that is sublime and once I have completed my new home over looking a deep blue lagoon, surrounded by banana tress and filled with fish, you can drop by for a pipe and a meal, and enjoy a sunset from my new deck!

80970975.review: I slept on the ground and a parasitic worm crawled into my skin. I had to fish it out with a bone needle. When I fished it out it informed me that I was it's dad and I'm legally obligated to provide for it. Or the worm just lowered my sanity. Either way, good game.

75866600.review:
As someone who's explored and lived in some parts of the Borneo rainforest, I can say Green Hell is fairly immersive. I can imagine the humidity just by looking at the glistening moisture of plants after the rain. The rainforest sounds resonate through a concerto of humming, buzzing, chirping and croaking. Done so convincingly to orchestrate a jungle teeming with life. I appreciate the devs effort into recreating a believable amazonian wildlife as well as the flora and fauna surrounding it. 

I can almost feel my primal instinct kick in as a jaguar slowly made its way towards me ready to pounce. I faced quite a number of fatal encounters whether it was crossing a river infested with piranhas or getting through the swamp with caimans. What separates the game from the rest of the survival titles is its good understanding on how the human body requires different nutrients to be fully nourished. Food poisoning, wound infections, parasitic infections, snake bites and leeches are some examples of adversities you'll likely face. 

I found crafting to be very satisfying although base building leaves much to be desired. Despite the bugs, the game has a solid premise and incredible potential to outshine other survival games. My only wish is for the devs to increase the variety of amazonian wildlife and allow them to interact with eact other. Carnivorous predators should be able to hunt other forms of prey. The surprisingly poignant story and the shocking conclusion makes up for its shortcomings. A must have for survival enthusiasts.

70963058.review:
As a brand new person to this game, I have to say I enjoy many things about it. My only real complaint seems to fall in line with most  other individuals who review this game. Your character has less energy than a 40yro asthmatic chain smoker and is thirstier than a 14yro kid at Hooters.



EDIT: So I found this wonderful thing that they have called CUSTOM difficulty. I basically max out all difficulty but set the Macroelement depletion to low. What you get is a pretty fun and still very hard game with the ability to not need to eat like a family of 4. You can select it for both story and survival, which makes this even more enjoyable. You can build things, and have time to explore but starvation/dehydration is still a threat.

Day 2: Eaten by Jaguar as I was carrying logs whistling "While You Work" to myself. 10/10

95695418.review:
Just like irl, in the first couple hours I killed and ate another human being. It drove me crazy and that was fun. Got tired real easy, couldn't find the right meds. Passed out on the forest floor, just meters from my shelter, in the pouring rain. Woke up with worms eating me. Fell into a death loop until I got the meds sorted out. Triumphant at my survival, went for a swim and was murdered by a snake. Just like irl. 

This game earns its name. #3 Top 5 survive-em-up on my list, after only The Forest and Subnautica. It's hard. It's gruesome and disgusting. It's muddy and bloody. You will suffer. Just like irl. 

I love it. And it's real pretty to boot.

66826253.review:
Green Hell is an incredibly appropriately named game. Everything you see is green, and everything is trying to kill you, slowly.

First attempt: got bitten repeatedly by a snake in the brush. Died.
Second attempt: tried to grab a poison dart frog for some reason. Died.
Third attempt: drank dirty water, got overwhelmed by parasites and badly dehydrated. No water. Died.
Fourth attempt: managed to collect some rainwater, and build a basic shelter, survived a couple days on mushrooms and bananas. Slowly going insane because of worms under my skin.

There are a lot of ways to die in Green Hell, and not a lot of ways to survive. That said, it's a hell of a lot of fun figuring out how things work, deciding on your next step, and struggling to pull it off, while not collapsing from exhaustion.

The presentation, graphics and sound design are all very good, though the crafting and building menu's are a bit clunky.

Apparently there's some other people that might not be friendly to encounter. Haven't lived long enough yet, but I'm going back to hell to try!

50069674.review:
Finally a game that not only resembles but actually compedes with Stranded II (the Survivalist mod). There has been a lot of "survival" games that honestly don't do much more than make you look for food and avoid predators/zombies. This game already puts them to shame. So, in short:
+ Beautiful graphics
+ Amazing realism to the survival aspect (!)
+ The mental health implementation is very good! The voices are disturping as hell, very well done. If anything, a few visual hallucinations would be nice - just some blurryness or change of light intensity or the like. EDIT: ignore the last part. The game does contain ... something visual :). 
+ Crafting systems are nice; one of them requires self-thinking (smaller stuff like axes), the other require that you find "blueprints" IE seeing it build somewhere. Larger stuff like snare traps.  

- You can't choose a game mode just without the indigenous people. Maybe that's just me wanting that. EDIT: this feature is coming up with the full release.
- You get quite a couple of notification icons that are not explained. I didn't get why my health kept declining that fast, and why I had to eat so much. I had a stomach icon with a number on it. 20-something. I thought it was the number of days I had gone without fullfilling my macronutrients. Seems like it was the number of parasites. Yuck. 

? Some people complain about having to watch your macronutrients. I like that idea, although I think it shouldn't be necessary to fill all three up at once. If you're eating a lot of protein and fats for a few days and then change to protein and carbohydrates, then the body should still be fine. So, good idea, I like it as it is, but a little flexibility would make it great. 
? The inventory system. I personally like that you have to move things around yourself - as in real life, you can package more stuff when you think about how to put it instead of just throwing it in there.

My first experience with the easy mode: 
I didn't recognize the eat-able plants at first. I didn't know where the "clean" water was. I couldn't cook the meat I'd found because I hadn't had the time to make a shelter for the fire, and it's a fucking rainforest, of course the rain will put the fire out. So I got food poisoning. Got dehydrated. Drank the dirty water in desperation. Got parasites. Collapsed because of lack of energy, in the mud. Woke up with worms. I could see the disgusting fucker dug into my skin, draining my sanity. Started hearing voices. I dug out the worm with a bone needle, and then wrapped up the open wound. The food poisoning was gone. I'd just found some coconuts. But I died anyway, because fuck parasites.
10/10 best way to die.

94163368.review:
It's somewhat similar to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/305620/The_Long_Dark/]The Long Dark[/url] but much easier. You can find a map, you have a compass which also shows your coordinates, there are no blizzards limiting visibility. Also, resources are plentiful and respawn quickly.

Oh, and there is base building! However, it's pretty bugged and if you want to build something bigger than 2x2, you are in for a disappointment.

The resources management is quite similar to that in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/242760]The Forest[/url] – some bigger resources you will have to carry in your hands rather than in your backpack. With no sled, building a base takes some running.


There are quite a lot of issues:
[list]
[*] no bulk crafting, nor automatic selection of resources once you know the recipe - you always have to drag all the ingredients onto the crafting interface one by one, and you have to remember the recipe
[*] all plants and fruits are called unknown
[*] you can save game only at the shelters you built
[*] invisible walls around most rocks so they cannot be jumped onto
[*] incorrect icons on the map whether grappling hook gun is required or just a grappling hook
[*] sometimes small dangerous animals walk into stones or stumps
[*] multiple snapping/collision issues when building, preventing you to build something bigger and more complex
[*] animals can attack you through walls/roofs of your shelter
[/list]

Despite all of these, the game is quite realistic and fun.

118150381.review:
Actually, I would recomment this game. The graphics look great, the story is fun, the survival mechanics are interesting and add good to the surroundings. It is just a very cool survival experience, which can get extremely easy though if you get the hang of it. The spirit of Amazonas Updates were free and cool. But there is a huge problem with survival mode, which is or would be my favorite game mode. 

The problem is: The lack of designing your own cozy spot. Your own base. Build, build, build. Because once you explored the map which probably takes a few in game days, to find all the blueprints if you know your way around and built the stuff you need like furnace, shower, a hut etc. there is nothing left to do except to sit there and wait for nothing. It´s actually game over then in survival mode. No threats, no hunger, no thirst, no disease and worst of all: Nothing to build. The devs really have to implement more buildables, such as decorations, more housing options, more stuff to work on like clothing, bridges, carts to transport wood, totems, plants, carved bones, planting trees and bushes, more different usable materiels to find that maybe also need a workbench to work further on it. different types of weapons, more options to light your camp, maybe options to make people move into your camp or enslave them to work for you. Survival mode needs a long term motivation. Things to actually pass time after day 10.. I don´t feel like building 10 empty mud huts, it is boring and dull. Survival mode is at some point not about survival anymore but about thinking about how you can pass time. So devs, give us the opportunity to make good fun of this time. Implement stuff. I want to be able to do more than just build a hut and thats it. I would throw away all spirit of Amazonia updates in exchange for this.

67701696.review: I have played allot of survival games...ALLOT, maybe too many, and this game is be far one of the best SURVIVAL games out there. I have a few things that I look for in a survival game, the most important being, is the game driven around actual survival? Is the most important game element survival? I find there's very few that answer yes to those 2 questions. Green Hell strives to always keep you completely engaged in every aspect of Survival. Time Management, Risk Management are the top factors of game play here,  What's crucial, is it isn't repetitive or simply crafting in repetition. Every moment of game play gets you closer to feeling like you are truely learning and gaining experience in surviving the Jungle. It's so engaging and immersive. The Crafting, the mechanics, the scenery, and the adversity, keep your attention literally all of the time. I've felt more engagement and content in the 50 hours I've played than I've felt in 100's of hours in other games. Every day is different and unique. I am eagerly looking forward to more content and enhancements.

65650077.review:
If you liked The Forest, you should like this.
From beginning to end this felt very much like The Forest, but I will try to describe the game without comparing it.

I played Green Hell as I like to play most Survival Games: By jumping in without reading reviews or guides, and seeing how far I can get just by following the game cues.
The survival system is mostly well explained via the notebook, and I was able to setup camp and get all needed resources by just following the cues. Although I do think I missed some easier ways to get water initially, as I felt I was always struggling to get fresh water (I refused to drink from the river directly). 

Anyway, the story is kinda cool too, and is essentially what drives the game.

Cons: I like achievements. I feel they are goals that the developer can set to drive most players to completing the game, and letting the player experience all the hard work that has gone into the game. Unfortunately this game has none. This meant that After I finished the story, I felt no need to try the survival mode or challenges. I know adding cheeves to games is usually very easy, so a couple of achievements for getting skills to certain levels or unlocking recipes or completing the challenge modes would have been easy to add and would have kept me playing the game a little longer.

All in all, a good experience. Even though I got this as a gift from a friend, I could still say I recommend it as a decent single player survival story.

123932988.review:
8/10, worth the price

Short:
If you like survival aka Stranded Deep, and you like some base building like The Forest, but also want a good story. This is the game for you.

Summary:

For me this game is surprisingly good, gripping story told through small amount of voice acting, visual story telling, memory sequences and found notes and voice recordings. Crafting and survival is focused and to the point. Medicinal uses of plants and balancing of macro nutrients is well designed. For the price 8/10. What let it down was that the crafting/base building felt disjointed compared to Subnautica. If that was handled better I would probably score 10/10.

Bug free:
I encountered no bugs, no crashes, no glitches.

Word of caution:
Be prepared to figure some stuff out. There are very few map markers. You have to find blueprints, and in some cases experimentally figure out how to build stuff. You don't know what plants you can eat till you try them. But if you shy away from trying anything you miss out on major medicinal herbs. You will probably die or go insane, probably both. BUT after a short but steep learning curve, you will become king of the jungle. No jaguar stands a chance, you will be ready for any sickness or malady. If you are on the brink, maybe google a bit to flatten the curve. But don't spoil too much. The map is not that big that losing a bit of progress is a big deal. 

First some small negatives: 

Some parts with the UI and inventory are a bit finicky, but everything works. Everyone who played this probably knows the trick of opening your backpack inventory to be able to drag rain filled coconuts on your fireplace. It works, but it will not win any beauty awards. Some of my friends found the crafting not intuitive. 

My main criticism:

I wish the base building and crafting factored more into the story, like it did with Subnautica. How it is now you can skip the whole basebuilding and only craft minimal necessities when pursuing the story. The "equipment" you need to progress is just found laying around. In contrast with Subnautica where you had to build new parts of your base to make new or upgraded equipment to progress. 
You can take lots of time to build your base with mud buildings. But when I started getting hooked by the story I was traveling fast and light, only crafting a bed, a roof, and a fire. You can craft metal objects, which is cool. I have seen Primitive Technology, cool that it is in the game. But you dont need any of it. One shot headshots with basic bow and arrow. Metal armor does make you basically invincible tho, but is too heavy if you travel with lots of stuff, and as the combat is at the moment you should have the upper hand any way.

Now the praise it deserves:

You really feel like Primitive Technology guy. Chopping trees, using palm leaves to make roofs. Using your fire drill to make a fire. Rooting through the forest to scrounge up something to eat: nuts, fruits, mushrooms. Making a spear to go spearfishing. Using different plants to create bandages and medicine against poison and fever. The Macronutrient system is simple but effective. If you cant find enough of a certain nutrient you will get tired much faster. 
The UI is minimal and you really start paying attention to the visuals and sound of the forest. Where is that plant I need, with the long leaves and the small yellow flowers? Is that the sound of a rattlesnake ready to strike, am I about to step on a poisonous spider? Is that my dinner making that noise, or is something hunting me for dinner?
The map and compass watch combination is well chosen. You basically know always where you are plus minus some metres, but it feels better immersion wise. But you first need to find the map ;) Be sure to note your base locations down. Only small comment is, i wish i could draw on the map.
The story gripped me pretty hard. This is probably very personal if you like it or not. But it felt like a real page turner for me. In the end I was rushing through the forest to find the next story beat, because I just had to know. Every location usually holds a small piece of the puzzle. Optional areas some notes or visuals to flash out the context, and the main story locations to bring it together. But the thing that drives it forward is... the pieces don't really fit. You can see the outline, and you can guess, but your guesses do not make sense, and you can't figure out how it should fit. You notice things do not add up fairly early, but things seem all out of whack near the 2/3 mark of the game. I haven't finished it, so I cannot tell you anything about the ending. I hope it has a well written ending.

76733696.review:
Green Hell uses 3 different game modes to allow the player to experience the game. Story, Survival, and Multiplayer are all available to try. If you are new to the title, you have an option to complete a tutorial.Green Hell maintains an open-world to explore and survive in with countless threats against your life without being a linear campaign. The story comes alive as you lose yourself in the rainforest, although it ends up on the backburner when danger creeps up on you.

+ Fantastic food and health management.
+ Gorgerous and believeable jungle athmosphere. 
+ Excellent lighting and weather effects.
+ Multiple ways to hunt, prepare and conserving food.
+ Standard loading times.
